I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In May 2007, the Government of the Lao People's Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) 
requested Asian Development Bank (ADB) assistance to strengthen the capacity of the Water 
Resources and Environment Administration (WREA). ADB provided technical assistance (TA)1 
to update the water resources policy and strategy and design the National Integrated Water 
Resources Management framework. An ADB fact-finding mission in May 2009 discussed the 
need and scope for further capacity development assistance. Understanding was reached on 
the terms of reference of consultants, cost estimates, and implementation arrangements for a 
capacity development technical assistance (CDTA), which was confirmed during a consultation 
mission in November 2009, when representatives of WREA, the Government of Australia, and 
ADB signed a memorandum of understanding. The design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The Lao PDR is the source of 38% of the annual flow of the Mekong River. Each country 
in the Mekong Basin3 perceives its future opportunities and risks related to water in a very 
different  way,  and  each  has  quite  different  human  resources  and  technical  and  financial 
capacity. Managing the Mekong will increasingly require riparian countries to address cross-
border issues, which will demand in turn strong national capacity to deal with complex issues 
regarding water use and resource protection. The formation of WREA in May 2007 was a 
significant step in strengthening capacity for integrated water resources management (IWRM)4 
in the Lao PDR, as it brings together several previously fragmented agencies and functions. 
Despite  rapid  development  in  the  water  sector,  the  Lao  PDR  has  lacked  the  capacity  to 
effectively implement IWRM. This has significantly limited its ability to (i) manage its own water 
resources  strategically  to  ensure  that  the  rapid  development  of  water-related  projects 
acceptably balances economic, social, and environmental concerns; and (ii) be an informed and 
equal partner in the international negotiations of the Mekong River Commission.5 
 
3.  Abundant water resources and mountainous terrain are the foundation for the expanding 
hydropower industry in the Lao PDR. While the need to regulate concessions that use water 
resources is recognized, the risk remains that the processes of granting water-use concessions 
could  limit  the  effectiveness  of  strengthened  IWRM  capacity.  In  addition  to  strengthening 
capacity for IWRM initiatives, WREA must strengthen its capacity for assessing environmental 
impact and enforcing environmental management plans to enable itself to fully implement its 
mandate.6   
 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2007. Technical Assistance to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic for Updating the National Water 
Resources Policy and Strategy. Manila (TA 7013-LAO, 12 December, in the amount of $1.0 million, including $0.5 
million cofinanced by the Government of Australia). The Government of Australia provided an additional $0.3 
million in 2009 for additional preparation activities for implementation of the proposed CDTA. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 21 April 2010. 
3  The lower Mekong Basin countries are Cambodia, the Lao PDR, Thailand, and Viet Nam. Upstream, Yunnan 
Province of the People’s Republic of China and Myanmar also have riparian access to Mekong water resources.   
4  IWRM promotes the coordinated development and management of water, land, and related resources to maximize 
economic and social benefits in an equitable manner without compromising the sustainability of vital ecosystems. 
By definition, management integrates planning and implementation.  
5  The lower Mekong Basin countries are members of the commission and use it to facilitate the resolution of trans-
boundary water issues. The proposed capacity development TA will complement the ongoing IWRM capacity 
building led by the commission secretariat in each member country. 
6  The Government of Finland is preparing TA to WREA specifically focused on the environmental mandate of the 
administration.

2   
4.  A multiplicity of sector agencies has roles in water resources management, and multiple 
levels  of  government  are  responsible  for  developing  and  conserving  water  and  related 
resources,  each  making  development  decisions  that  affect  water  resources.  As  in  many 
countries, the objective of rapid economic development can collide with sustainable natural 
resource  use  and  the  equitable  sharing  of resources  and  their  benefits  among  traditional, 
existing, and new water users. An important challenge for WREA is to engage government and 
resource-using  sectors  in  river  basin  planning  and  management  to  efficiently  achieve 
sustainable and fair water use. A key issue is how to adopt the results of river basin and sub-
basin plans into the formal government planning process efficiently and effectively. While there 
is  some  regional  experience  with  IWRM  and  river  basin  and  sub-basin  planning,  there  is 
concern  that  the  planning  processes  not  become  the  dominating  activity  and  delay  the 
implementation of necessary and important investments and other actions. Thus, it is important 
for  river  basin  planning  and  IWRM  to  accommodate  and  facilitate  obviously  necessary 
investments without unnecessary delay, while maintaining adequate safeguards, rights, and 
responsibilities.  
 
5.  In June 2010, the government approved the Decree on Establishment and Activities of 
River Basin Committees. The Lao PDR has established the first river basin committee, in the 
Nam Ngum Basin, and is testing the new institutional arrangements to facilitate coordination 
among sectors and levels of government.  These are significant changes in the way that natural 
resources are allocated and managed. These changes require careful introduction with strong 
political  will  and  leadership  to  ensure  that  all  stakeholders  are  aligned  with  the  new 
management regimes as they are established. The TA will help build the institutional and human 
resources required to implement the National Water Resources Policy and Strategy7 that will 
guide activities in the water sector and will provide timely assistance to support the development 
of basin committees and assist in the mobilization of stakeholders. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  The impact of the National Integrated Water Resources Management Support Project 
will be that water resources are managed in the Lao PDR river basins for sustainable economic, 
social, and environmental objectives. The outcome of the TA will be that the necessary human 
resources and institutional capacity will have been established in WREA, river basin committees, 
their secretariats, and other key agencies for integrated water resources management.   
 
7.  The TA will contribute to the implementation of the National Integrated Water Resources 
Management Support Program.8 It will assist the government: (i) establish gender-responsive 
professional development programs for WREA staff; (ii) implement appropriate governance 
systems  for  project  management,  monitoring,  and  evaluation;  (iii)  establish  institutional 
arrangements  for  river  basin  management;  (iv)  provide  updates  on  the  inventory  of  water 
resources and their utilization; and (v) assist the development of formal university education in 
IWRM at the National University of Lao (NUOL).  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The outputs of the project will provide the foundations for a national approach to IWRM 
including river basin and sub-basin planning and management, and equip the Lao PDR to 
participate more equally and effectively in regional activities. The support project will provide a 
                                                 
7  WREA. 2010. National Water Resources Strategy and Action Plan for the Years 2011–2015. Vientiane (mimeo). 
8  The National Integrated Water Resources Support Program is the framework used by WREA to coordinate donor 
funds  with  resources  available  through  the  national  budget.  The  framework  includes  ten  components 
designed to establish the necessary capacity for IWRM in Lao PDR.

3
road map for achieving effective IWRM and provide WREA with a nationally owned project as a 
basis  for  (i)  strategic  planning  in  the  sector;  (ii)  human  resources  development;  (iii)  the 
institutional upgrading of water resource data collection, management, and processing; (iv) work 
and budget planning; and (v) the coordinated mobilization of resources from the government 
and external development partners.  
 
9.  The TA will be implemented over 4 years with four outputs designed to complement 
activities funded by other development partners which are outside the scope of ADB TA.9 The 
TA outputs will directly assist in implementing the water resources strategy and action plan 
(footnote 7). Each package will focus on outputs that contribute to the outcome of positioning 
WREA at the center of sustainable IWRM, with resource development and water services 
provided through appropriate line agencies and the private sector. The TA will help WREA to (i) 
identify entry points for mainstreaming climate change concerns in water resources planning 
and management at both the policy and operational level and (ii) strengthen the capacity of 
decision makers to climate-proof water infrastructure. The TA will extend the impact of support 
to WREA capacity building for climate change adaptation.10  
 
10.  Output 1: National capacity built in integrated water resources management. The 
project will help the WREA cabinet and participating departments to implement appropriate 
project  and  project  management  systems  to  ensure  good  governance  of  the  project  and 
subsequent  WREA  operations.  The  TA  will  focus  immediately  on  building  the  capacity  of 
WREA’s  project  management  unit  (PMU),  located  in  the  Department  of  Water  Resources 
(DWR), to effectively coordinate project management and serve as the secretariat of the project 
national steering committee. It will support continuing professional development for WREA staff 
in cooperation with relevant WREA departments, Mekong River Commission training projects, 
and the NUOL. Training courses will be aimed at management, technicians, and trainers of 
trainers. Capacity development will include priority training projects for the staff of national 
agencies;  emerging  basin  organizations;  provincial  agencies;  and  academic,  private,  and 
nongovernment  organizations.  Training  will  be  provided  on  the  role  of  IWRM  and  basin 
management  in  climate  change  adaption  and  mitigation  in  rural  communities.  Capacity 
development  will  promote  actions  to  help  implement  the  gender  action  plan  of  the  Prime 
Minister’s Office and develop a gender action plan to ensure that WREA capacity development 
and field operations are implemented in gender responsive way. 
11.  The WREA professional development program will coordinate capacity development and 
training across the organization to ensure that appropriate training opportunities and subjects 
are available to WREA management and staff in coordination with other capacity development 
programs, including that of the Mekong River Commission. 
 
12.  The  TA  will  help  WREA  to  establish  gender  disaggregated  project  monitoring  and 
evaluation systems and the necessary performance management capability in the monitoring 
and  evaluation  unit  in  the  WREA  Cabinet  Office  to  implement  the  WREA  monitoring 
framework.11 
 
 
                                                 
9  Pipeline support for WREA: (i) World Bank Mekong Integrated Water Resources Management Project (Lao PDR 
component estimated at $4.0 million), late 2010; (ii) Government of Finland estimated at $8.0 million, 2010, 
German development cooperation through KfW in kind support for basin management, 2010. A shared project 
management unit is being established by WREA with the assistance of ADB TA (footnote 1). 
10 ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic for Capacity Enhancement for Coping 
with Climate Change. Manila (TA 7509-LAO, for $3.1 million, approved on 11 March). 
11  GHD 2010. National Water Resource Strategy Implementation and Monitoring. Completion Report. Vientiane 
(September, mimeo).

4   
13.  Output 2: River basin management developed. The project will help WREA develop 
and implement IWRM in river basins, including dealing with large projects in water resources 
development, working across sectors and with communities and the private and public sectors. 
The TA will focus on developing and testing appropriate river basin institutional arrangements 
adapted to local conditions in selected pilot river basins,12 ultimately leading to river basin plans 
being integrated into government  planning and investment decisions. The TA will promote 
IWRM as key to mainstreaming climate change adaptation into resource management in the 
Lao PDR. Three case studies will help develop specific climate change adaptation interventions 
in the Nam Ngum Basin relevant at both the farm and sub-basin level to assess barriers and 
identify potential countermeasures.13 The national water resources inventory will be updated to 
categorize basins and to identify critical IWRM issues and locations. 
 
14.  Output 3: National groundwater management action plan prepared. The project will 
assist  the  WREA  units  responsible  for  groundwater  management  in  preparing  an  initial 
approach to and action plan for managing groundwater systematically for sustainable use. The 
TA will enable WREA to (i) assess key public and private stakeholders and their groundwater 
information needs and uses and assess institutional, policy, and standards settings; (ii) assess 
existing information, data, and the understanding of key stakeholders and estimate, on a river 
basin and groundwater basin basis, probable groundwater resources, conditions, usage, and 
demand;  (iii)  evaluate  monitoring  networks  and  databases,  practices,  and  procedures  and 
recommend improvements; and (iv) assess the training needs of groundwater management 
specialists, including identifying the units and/or staff members to target, so that the training is 
relevant and focused. 
 
15.  Output 4: Integrated water resources management education strengthened at the 
National  University  of  Laos.  The  project  will  assist  the  Water  Resource  Engineering 
Department (WRED) of the NUOL in preparing the strategic plan and detailed proposals for 
bachelor-level qualification in IWRM. The TA will initiate the retraining of WRED teaching staff 
and support the in-house development of the strategic plan and proposals for future support. 
WRED will review IWRM good practices and implementation experience, as well as governance 
and  institutions;  stewardship;  management  devolution  to  the  lowest  appropriate  level; 
organizational functions at the national, river basin, and local level; and stakeholder participation 
in  decision-making  regarding  the  trade-offs  among  economic,  social,  and  environmental 
objectives. Specialist assistance will be provided to advise the curriculum development team on 
mainstreaming climate change into the IWRM degree project at the NUOL. The strategic plan 
and detailed proposal will present the rationale for the proposed curriculum and retraining of 
teaching  staff,  including  a  design  and  monitoring  framework  and  detailed  monitoring  and 
evaluation plans as the basis for seeking support for tertiary IWRM training. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $4,210,000, toward which the government has requested 
ADB financing of $3,900,000 (Appendix 2). ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV) 
will finance $300,000 as a grant. The Government of Australia A$3,200,000, and the Spanish 
Cooperation Fund for Technical Assistance $600,000 will provide grant finance administered by 
ADB. The government will finance the balance equivalent of $310,000 in kind by providing 
counterpart staff, offices, and other support required for implementing the TA. Output 1 is 
estimated to cost $1,125,000; output 2 $2,245,000; output 3 $535,000; and output 4 $305,000. 
Additional financing may be sought for a second phase based on an evaluation of progress 
                                                 
12 The Nam Ngum River Basin Committee, managed by the newly created River Basin Committee Secretariat in 
Vientiane Province, is the priority basin because of ongoing hydropower and mine development.  
13 Interventions may include water harvesting, zero tillage, changing cropping patterns and varieties, water allocation 
and sharing, increasing water storage capacity, reusing wastewater, and water pricing and water rights.

5
toward  the  end  of  year  3  of  implementation.  Evidence  of  the  development  of  sustainable 
financing of WREA and RBC operations will be monitored and assessed during implementation. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  WREA will be the executing agency for the overall support project. WREA has appointed 
a national project director in the DWR to lead the PMU.14 The implementing agencies for the TA 
are (i) the WREA PMU for output 1, (ii) the DWR in partnership with river basin committees and 
their secretariats (footnote 12) for output 2, (iii) the Water and Environment Research Institute 
and the DWR for output 3, and (iv) the NUOL Water and Engineering Department for output 4. 
The monitoring and evaluation of the overall progress of the support project will be by the 
WREA Cabinet Office Project Monitoring and Evaluation Unit following the agreed monitoring 
framework (footnote 11). A national steering committee and development partner group will 
guide project implementation. ADB, the Government of Australia, and the Government of Spain 
will participate in semiannual joint review missions. The TA will be implemented over a 4-year 
period expected to commence in early 2011. Consulting services packages will be approved for 
implementation based on the progress of the TA following reviews by ADB, the Australian 
Agency for International Development, the Government of Spain, and WREA to ensure WREA 
has the capacity to absorb additional project inputs. 
 
18.  Consulting  services  will  total  269  person-months,  comprising  66  person-months  of 
international consultancy and 203 person-months of national consultancy in five packages. The 
outline  terms  of  reference  for  consultants  are  in  Appendix  3.  International  and  national 
consultants will be recruited by the PMU through consulting firms using ADB’s quality- and cost-
based system at a ratio of 90:10,15 with either simplified or full technical proposals.16 Individual 
consultants may be engaged for special studies and TA following agreement between WREA 
and ADB on assignments. All consultants will be recruited by ADB following its Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The procurement of equipment 
for the TA will follow ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time), and 
all equipment will be transferred to the implementing agencies on TA completion. The proceeds 
of the TA will be disbursed in line with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION AND DECISION 
19.  The President recommends that the Board approve ADB administering a portion of 
technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of A$3,200,000 to the Lao PDR for the 
 
National Integrated Water Resources Management Support Project, to be financed on a grant 
basis by the Government of Australia. If the Board approves ADB administering the technical 
assistance, the President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, will approve (i) 
ADB  administering  a  portion  of  the  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$600,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Spanish Cooperation Fund for Technical 
Assistance; and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a 
grant basis for the National Integrated Water Resources Management Support Project. 
                                                 
14 The PMU will be established before the capacity development TA is effective. The procedures and accounting 
systems for the PMU are being developed through consulting services provided by TA 7013-LAO during 2010. The 
PMU will manage the World Bank-financed Mekong IWRM Project in the Lao PDR, due for approval in 2011. 
15 A ratio of 90:10 is proposed to meet the need for high-quality consulting services for this project. 
16 Simplified technical proposals will be used for packages 3 and 4, which are budgeted at less than $600,000.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will provide the foundations for a national approach to 
integrated water resources management (IWRM), including river basin and sub-basin planning 
and  management,  and  will  equip  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic  (Lao  PDR)  to 
participate more equally and effectively in regional activities. The support project will provide a 
road map for achieving effective IWRM and provide the Water Resources and Environment 
Administration (WREA) with a nationally owned program as a basis for: (i) strategic planning in 
the sector; (ii) human resource development; (iii) the institutional upgrading of water resources 
data  collection,  management,  and  processing;  (iv)  work  and  budget  planning;  and  (v)  the 
coordinated mobilization of resources from the government and external development partners.

2.  WREA will be the executing agency. The TA will be implemented over 4 years toward 
four outputs designed to complement activities supported through parallel funding by other 
development  partners.  The  outputs  will  directly  assist  in  the  implementation  of  the  water 
resources strategy and action plan.1 The TA will focus on achieving outputs that contribute to 
the expected outcome of positioning WREA at the center of sustainable IWRM, with resource 
development and sectoral water services delivery provided through appropriate line agencies 
and  the  private  sector.  The  required  consulting services  are  summarized  in  Table  A3.  All 
consultants will be recruited by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) following its Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The procurement of equipment 
for the TA will follow ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). An

Appendix 3     11 
international water governance specialist will act as chief technical adviser, and a national river 
basin management specialist will be the deputy team leader. The TA will undertake the tasks 
outlined below, which may be adjusted by the Government of the Lao PDR and WREA, with 
prior approval by ADB in consultation with the cofinancing partners. 
 
B.  Scope of Services 
 
3.  Package 1: National integrated water resources capacity building (full technical 
proposal).  The  TA  will  assist  WREA  by  (i)  building  capacity  and  helping  WREA  and  the 
Department of Water Resources to effectively implement IWRM in the Lao PDR and participate 
in international forums; (ii) building capacity and strengthening governance capacity for the 
National  Integrated  Water  Resources  Management  Support  Project,  including  coordinating 
donors and the activities of other line agencies; and (iii) providing advice and assistance for 
implementing the National Water Resources Policy and Strategy, including further developing 
and implementing national policy, laws, decrees, strategies, implementation and monitoring 
plans, and guidelines. 
 
4.  Package 2: River basin management (full technical proposal). The TA will help 
WREA, led by the Department of Water Resources in central and provincial offices,2 to (i) 
develop and implement integrated river basin management, including dealing with large projects 
in water resource development, working across sectors and with communities and the private 
and public sectors; (ii) update the national water resources inventory to identify basins under 
stress or likely to become so, as a basis for selecting priority basins for river basin management 
institutional development; and (iii) establish appropriate institutional arrangements for river basin 
management through testing and adaptation to local conditions in selected pilot river basins.  
 
5.  Package  3:  Groundwater  resources  assessment  (simplified  technical 
proposal).The TA will help WREA to manage groundwater systematically.  It will (i) improve 
understanding of the likely extent, usage, and condition of groundwater resources, as well as 
risks to them; (ii) propose arrangements for improved groundwater monitoring; (iii) train staff 
directly involved in groundwater management at the center and in the provinces; and (iv) 
develop an initial national framework and action plan to manage groundwater. 
 
6.  Package 4: Developing integrated water resources management education at the 
National University of Laos (simplified technical proposal). The TA will help the Water 
Resources and Engineering Department (WRED) of the National University of Laos to establish 
graduate and postgraduate education in IWRM. The TA will (i) review the curricula of regional 
universities and institutes, particularly those offering specialist IWRM courses; (ii) implement a 
study tour for senior WRED staff; and (iii) facilitate a twinning agreement with one or more 
universities and/or institutes covering teacher exchange, in-country training, and bachelor’s and 
master’s degree courses. The consultants and WRED teaching staff will prepare a strategic plan 
and detailed proposal for implementing the curriculum, including the rationale for the proposed 
curriculum and retraining of teaching staff, a design and monitoring framework, and a detailed 
monitoring and evaluation (M&E) plan.3  
 
7.  Package  5:  Individual  specialists  and  unallocated  person-months.  The  TA  will 
maintain a degree of flexibility in consulting services with the allocation of an additional 16 
person-months of international consulting services. This includes an initial allocation of 10 
person-months of IWRM specialist services to advise WREA on strategic issues and critical 
decisions. A national gender specialist (5 person-months) will be recruited to assist WREA 
develop a gender action plan for seeking additional financing.

C.   Reporting and Workshops 
 
8.  For each package the consultants will produce the following reports: 
 (i)  The inception report, submitted at the end of the first month after mobilization, 
will  present  initial  findings  and  assessments  and  detailed  work  and  staff 
schedules.  The  inception  report  will  be  discussed  with  stakeholders  at  an 
inception workshop held 2 weeks after its submission.  
(ii)   The  midterm  report  will  be  submitted  at  about  the  midpoint  of  package 
implementation.  It  will  present  progress  to  date,  details  of  progress  towards 
project objectives, and plans for the remaining project period. The midterm report 
and its preliminary recommendations will be discussed with stakeholders at a 
midterm workshop held 2 weeks after its submission. 
(iii)   The draft final report will be submitted about 6 weeks before the end of package 
implementation. The findings and recommendations of each package will be 
discussed at the final tripartite workshop.  
(iv)   The final report will be submitted 2 weeks after the final tripartite workshop, with 
revisions from comments at the workshop and all other official comments. 
 
D.  Facilities  to  be  provided  by  the  Government  of  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic 
Republic 
 
9.  The government will provide the following facilities to the TA team: (i) access to project 
sites, project reports, records, and other information required for TA studies; (ii) office space; (iii) 
local transport in Vientiane; and (iv) counterpart staff to help consultants implement the TA.  
 
E.   Outline Terms of Reference for Technical Assistance Specialists 
 
10.  Chief  technical  advisor,  water  governance  specialist  (international,  25  person-
months). The chief technical advisor (CTA) will, in consultation with ADB and the TA project 
director, coordinate TA activities with agencies and development partners. The CTA will lead TA 
implementation  in  coordination  with  the  WREA  project  director  and  other  project  teams 
supporting WREA. The CTA will manage: (i) the implementation of package 1 for developing the 
overall  governance  systems  for  implementing  the  National  IWRM  Support  Program,  to  be 
utilized by WREA when coordinating activities funded by other development partners; (ii) the 
development and implementation of a training needs assessment and capacity building for 
WREA staff in national and provincial offices; (iii) the preparation of TA methodologies and work 
and staff schedules, support monitoring and evaluation of the NIWRM-SP, and preparation of 
key TA reports; and (iv) assistance to senior WREA management for preparing strategic plans 
and  publications.  The  CTA  will  have  at  least  15  years’  experience  in  water  resources 
management in Southeast Asia. 
 
11.  River basin management specialist (international, 15 person-months). As team leader 
for package 2, the consultant will be a highly experienced international expert with relevant 
qualifications; have experience and specialization in river basin and sub-basin management, 
including river basin and sub-basin planning and river basin and sub-basin organizations; and 
have extensive experience in the Mekong region, preferably in the Lao PDR. The expert will 
have strong project management, interpersonal, and communication skills; be fluent in written 
and spoken English; and have proven ability to write professional reports.  
 
12.  Groundwater resources specialist (international, 4 person-months). The specialist will 
have  relevant  qualifications  and  a  minimum  of  15  years  of  practical  experience  and 
specialization  in  hydrogeology,  groundwater  modeling,  and  groundwater  management.  The

Appendix 3     13 
specialist will lead the assessment of (i) public and private stakeholders; their groundwater 
information  needs  and  use;  and  institutional,  policy,  and  standards  settings;  (ii)  existing 
information, data, and understanding of key stakeholders for estimating, on river basin and 
groundwater basin bases, likely groundwater resources, conditions, usage, and demand; (iii) 
monitoring  networks  and  databases,  practices,  and  procedures,  with  recommendations  for 
improvements; and (iv) the training needs for groundwater management specialists, including 
the identification of specific units and staff members to target so that the training is relevant and 
focused. Relevant experience in developing countries is required, including in the Mekong 
region  and,  preferably,  in  the  Lao  PDR.  Also  required  are  good  interpersonal  and 
communication skills and proven ability to speak fluently and write concise and clear reports in 
English on deadline. 
 
13.  Integrated water resources management advisor (international, 10 person-months). 
The specialist will have a minimum of 25 years’ experience in water resources management and 
demonstrated experience in advising governments with regard to water resource management 
issues. The specialist will have a minimum of 10 years’ relevant experience in the Mekong 
region. The specialist will provide intermittent inputs over the duration of the TA in response to 
the requirements of WREA management.  
 
14.  Integrated  water  resources  management  curriculum  development  specialist 
(international, 6 person-months). The specialist will be a qualified water resources engineer with 
a strong academic and teaching background whose experience includes the (i) preparation and 
implementation  of  IWRM  degree  programs,  (ii)  development  and  implementation  of  formal 
training and university education in water resources subjects, and (iii) development of practical 
on-the-job  training  and  participatory  learning  by  doing.  The  specialist  will  have  strong 
interpersonal and communication skills and proven ability to speak fluently and write concise 
professional reports in English.   
 
15.  Monitoring and evaluation specialist (international, 5 person-months). The specialist 
will have a strong background in project M&E, with experience in information systems. The 
specialist  will  have  demonstrated  experience  in  setting  up  M&E  systems,  including  the 
development of performance criteria, practical monitoring, and evaluation and reporting systems 
that support the implementation and management of complex programs. The specialist will work 
closely with the WREA monitoring and evaluation unit and the national M&E specialist and must, 
therefore, have strong interpersonal and communication skills, as well as proven ability to speak 
fluently and write concise professional reports in English.  
 
16.  Unallocated individual specialists (international, 1 person-month). A total of 1 person-
months  of  individual  international  specialist  consultancy  can  be  utilized  to  support  TA 
implementation through agreement on terms of reference and outputs between WREA and 
ADB. The specialists will be recruited using procedures acceptable to ADB. 
 
17.  River basin management specialist (national 30 person-months). In collaboration with 
the international river basin specialist, the specialist will help the river basin organization in the 
Nam Ngum Basin become an effective planning and management agency. The specialist will 
have  over  5  years’  experience  in  IWRM  and  experience  with  developing  institutions  and 
participatory planning techniques. 
 
18.  Institutions development specialist (national 33 person-months). In collaboration with 
the  international  river  basin  management  specialist,  the  consultant  will  (i)  help  the  chief 
technical  advisor  review  current  national,  regional,  and  river  basin  policy  environments  for 
IWRM implementation; and (ii) help WREA strengthen the capacity of river basin organizations 
in the Lao PDR.

14  Appendix 3 
 
19.  IWRM training specialist (national 30 person-months). In collaboration with the chief 
technical advisor, the specialist will undertake a training needs assessment; develop training 
modules and programs, including on-the-job training and continuing professional development 
programs, for WREA management, professional staff, and technicians to strengthen technical 
capacity to implement IWRM in the Lao PDR. 
 
20.  Administration and finance specialist (national, 39 person-months). The specialist will 
have qualifications in administration and finance and 10 years of relevant experience. The 
specialist will work in the Program Management Unit to assist the national project director and 
staff  in  managing  the  National  Integrated  Water  Resources  Management  Support  Project, 
including subprojects and components funded by other development partners. Experience in 
working on internationally funded projects, national administration procedures, and emerging 
public financial management procedures is essential. Also required are experience in staff 
management and budgeting; demonstrated capacity to manage staff; and the ability to speak, 
read, and write in English. 
 
21.  Climate change adaptation specialist (national, 4 person-months). In collaboration 
with the international climate change specialist, the specialist will assist WREA day-to-day 
operations to mainstream climate change adaptation. 
 
22.  Participatory planning specialist (national, 18 person-months). The specialist will help 
river  basin  management  specialists  to  develop  and  implement  mechanisms  to  enable  the 
effective participation of all stakeholder groups in developing and monitoring river basin plans.  
 
23.  Groundwater resources specialist (national, 20 person-months). With guidance from 
the international specialist, the national specialist will assess: (i) stakeholders groundwater 
information needs; (ii) existing information, likely groundwater resources, conditions, usage, and 
demand; (iii) monitoring networks, databases, practices, and procedures, with recommendations 
for  improvements;  and  (iv)  the  training  needs  for  groundwater  management  specialists, 
including the identification of specific units and staff members to target so that the training is 
relevant and focused. Good interpersonal and communication skills and proven ability to speak 
fluently and write concise and clear reports in English on deadline is required. 
 
24.  Integrated water resources water management education specialists (national, 2 
specialists, 6 person-months each). The specialist will, in coordination with the international 
curriculum development specialist and the climate change specialist, (i) assist the WRED of the 
National  University  of  Laos  develop  an  updated  curriculum  and  course  materials  for  the 
undergraduate IWRM course; (ii) establish partnerships or twinning arrangements with leading 
educational institutions in the region; and (iii) establish post-graduation employment strategies. 
 
25.  Gender specialist (national, 5 person-months). The specialist will assist the consultants 
and WREA in ensuring that all activities and training are gender responsive and consistent with 
National Commission for Advancement of Women strategies. The Specialist will assist WREA to 
prepare a gender action plan for additional financing to support gender-sensitive actions for 
implementing the national IWRM policy and strategy. 
 
26.  Monitoring and evaluation specialist (national, 12 person-months). The specialist will 
have experience in project M&E and the capacity to help WREA develop and implement the 
information  systems  necessary  to  make  the  performance  M&E  system  operational.  The 
specialist  should  have  practical  experience  in  setting  up  M&E  systems,  including  the 
development of performance criteria, practical monitoring, and evaluation and reporting systems, 
including  communication  planning,  that  support  the  implementation  and  management  of 
complex programs.
